description:
Suncus etruscus, commonly known as the Etruscan shrew, is a species of small insectivorous mammal belonging to the family Soricidae. It is the smallest known mammal species in the world, with an average adult weight of only around 1.8 grams.

The Etruscan shrew is native to parts of Europe and Asia, including countries such as Italy, Spain, Portugal, and parts of North Africa. It has a small, elongated body with a pointed snout, small eyes, and short limbs. Its fur is typically dark brown or gray in color. 

This species is known for its high metabolic rate and rapid heartbeat, which can reach up to 1,200 beats per minute. This high rate of metabolism is necessary to sustain its high energy demands, as it must consume large amounts of food relative to its body size to maintain its active lifestyle.

Etruscan shrews are solitary and territorial animals, occupying small home ranges. They primarily feed on small invertebrates, such as insects, spiders, and other small arthropods. These shrews are important components of their local ecosystems, playing a role in the regulation of invertebrate populations.

Due to their small size and secretive nature, Etruscan shrews are challenging to study in the wild, and their conservation status is classified as Least Concern by the IUCN.
